Barmouth is on the A496 west of Dolgellau and south of Harlech.
Barmouth is on the Cambrian Coast
Barmouth is served by the Traws-Cambria

Yacht moorings are available at Barmouth harbour. Harbourmaster: +44 1341 280671

value: The land train takes you from the Bath House by the harbour to the north end of the promenade during the tourist season.
Ferries take you from Barmouth harbour to The Point at Fairbourne where you can get the narrow gauge railway into Fairbourne.
content=Tells the story of a local shipwreck of 1709, and the subsequent salvage operation. Includes some surprisingly well-preserved relics.
price=Free, but do make a donation as the lifeboats are entirely volunteer-run.

content=See the lifeboat and the specialist tractor that pulls it across the beach to the sea. Displays about past rescues and the different equipment used by the crew. Gift shop open in summer months and on weekends all year.
. After several replacement initial letter "C"s had been bought for the sign, the owner finally gave up and reverted to the current name.
, which starts in Barmouth each June. This test of endurance involves boats carrying teams of sailors and runners, and ascents of the 3 highest mountains in each of Wales,
, run to the summit of Snowdon and back to the boat, sail on to
and run up and down Scafell Pike, and finally sail to
and run up and down Ben Nevis. The first running team to get back to Fort William from the summit of the Ben are declared the winners.
Visit Dinas Oleu, the very first donation to the National Trust

in 1895. This was originally a 4.5 acre site which later donations extended to some 17.5 acres. Meaning Fortress of Light - the land is high on the hillside above the town and provides a marvellous viewpoint to look out over the northern part of Cardigan Bay. In the centenary year, 1995, NT built a commemorative seat on the site from local stone.

to Morfa Mawddach. This is a railway bridge and has no access to road vehicles, but pedestrians and cyclists can use it. The walkway offers stunning views up the Mawddach Estuary, the subject of a million picture postcards. The walk can be extended along the

value: Catch the ferry across the river to Penrhyn Point

, where you can catch the Fairbourne Railway

around Barmouth. This is a facinating trip on foot around the historical wealth of Barmouth. A map and information is available at each location -just point and click at the QR coded plaques around the town. Alternatively, you can obtain a printed map from Barmouth Tourist Information Centre.

value: content=Climbing haphazardly up the steep slopes at the back of the High Street, the paths and alleys of old Barmouth reveal many quaint and delightful corners. Houses seem to be built almost on top of one another in this fascinating jumble of steps and terraces

content=Barmouth developed as one of the major ship building centres in Wales during the 18th & 19th centuries. The harbour still has a small fishing industry but is mainly used by pleasure craft. The estuary is home to Merioneth Yacht Club. Lining the edge of the harbour are cafes, ice-cream parlours and a pub with pleasant gardens to sit out in and watch the world go by

content=Internationally well-known due to having been featured in numerous Sunday Supplement articles and TV travel or food show items. Large bins are lined up throughout the shop floor, containing goods such as sweets, dried fruit, nuts, seeds, flour, powdered soup and so on. You simply scoop as much or as little as you want into bags and "weigh out" the required amount. Great value.And very pleasant staff a rare thing these days
content=Factory outlet store for Regatta outdoor clothing. Typically 30-40% cheaper than the full retail price.
content=Stocks a wide range of gifts, cards and homewares.

content=Located in one of Barmouth's oldest buildings, dating from the 15th Century. Atmospheric maritime-themed decor inside, but if the weather allows you will want one of the tables at the outside terrace, offering great views across the harbour, the river, and the mountains beyond. Good range of soups, sandwiches, salads and some more substantial dishes.
content=Friendly pub with a fascinating historic interior. Live music nights every Tuesday. Good quality and value food too.
hours=Open Friday and Saturday until 2AM, other nights as advertised
content=Barmouths only nightclub, attracts clientele from many other towns in the area. A range of entertainment including 70s and 80's, motown, soul and reggae  nights, also teenage discos.

content=The offers some of the most spectacular views in Wales from its perch above the famous Barmouth railway bridge. Although just ten minutes walk to the harbour-side restaurants the location is quiet and peaceful, surrounded by woodlands and a myriad of wild birds. Open all year. Eight rooms, (6 double, 2 twin).

content=Bryn Melyn is a small, well appointed hotel, renowned for its relaxed atmosphere and friendly welcome. Recommended by Which and other guides, it is situated in its own grounds, in an elevated position on the mountainside, with superb views across the Mawddach estury.
content=Four newly renovated one bed-roomed self catering units situated between Barmouth and Dolgellau.
content=4 star bungalow with 2 bedrooms, sleeps up to 4 adults. Good views over Cardigan Bay from large conservatory. Set  in quiet cul-de-sac off A496.
name=Beautiful Wales Sea View Luxury Holiday Barns
address=Ceilwart Ganol Farm, Llanaber, Barmouth LL42 1YS
directions=Just off the main road - look for our signs

content=5 Star Holiday barns with stunning sea views from the lounge and decking of Penty Buwch and Penty Mochyn.  Situated on an equestrian property that is also home to chickens, ducks, grey faced dartmoor sheep and sometimes pigs.
address=21 Marine Parade, Barmouth, Gwynedd, LL42 1NA
content=8 bedroom guest house family friendly at the end of Marine Parade, closest guest house to beach.
